name: Data.List.Lazy
comments:
This module defines a type of _lazy_ linked lists, and associated helper
functions and type class instances.

_Note_: Depending on your use-case, you may prefer to use
`Data.Sequence` instead, which might give better performance for certain
use cases. This module is an improvement over `Data.Array` when working with
immutable lists of data in a purely-functional setting, but does not have
good random-access performance.

declarations.comments:
Convert a list into any unfoldable structure.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: toUnfoldable

declarations.comments:
Construct a list from a foldable structure.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: fromFoldable

declarations.comments:
Create a list with a single element.

Running time: `O(1)`
declarations.title: singleton

declarations.comments: An infix synonym for `range`.
Create a list containing a range of integers, including both endpoints.
declarations.title: range

declarations.comments: Create a list with repeated instances of a value.
declarations.title: replicate

declarations.comments: Perform a monadic action `n` times collecting all of the results.
declarations.title: replicateM

declarations.comments:
Attempt a computation multiple times, requiring at least one success.

The `Lazy` constraint is used to generate the result lazily, to ensure
termination.
declarations.title: some

declarations.comments:
Attempt a computation multiple times, returning as many successful results
as possible (possibly zero).

The `Lazy` constraint is used to generate the result lazily, to ensure
termination.
declarations.title: many

declarations.comments: Create a list by repeating an element
declarations.title: repeat

declarations.comments: Create a list by iterating a function
declarations.title: iterate

declarations.comments: Create a list by repeating another list
declarations.title: cycle

declarations.comments:
Test whether a list is empty.

Running time: `O(1)`
declarations.title: null

declarations.comments:
Get the length of a list

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: length

declarations.comments:
Append an element to the end of a list, creating a new list.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: snoc

declarations.comments:
Insert an element into a sorted list.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: insert

declarations.comments:
Insert an element into a sorted list, using the specified function to determine the ordering
of elements.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: insertBy

declarations.comments:
Get the first element in a list, or `Nothing` if the list is empty.

Running time: `O(1)`.
declarations.title: head

declarations.comments:
Get the last element in a list, or `Nothing` if the list is empty.

Running time: `O(n)`.
declarations.title: last

declarations.comments:
Get all but the first element of a list, or `Nothing` if the list is empty.

Running time: `O(1)`
declarations.title: tail

declarations.comments:
Get all but the last element of a list, or `Nothing` if the list is empty.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: init

declarations.comments:
Break a list into its first element, and the remaining elements,
or `Nothing` if the list is empty.

Running time: `O(1)`
declarations.title: uncons

declarations.comments: An infix synonym for `index`.

Get the element at the specified index, or `Nothing` if the index is out-of-bounds.

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the required index.
declarations.title: index

declarations.comments: Find the index of the first element equal to the specified element.
declarations.title: elemIndex

declarations.comments: Find the index of the last element equal to the specified element.
declarations.title: elemLastIndex

declarations.comments: Find the first index for which a predicate holds.
declarations.title: findIndex

declarations.comments: Find the last index for which a predicate holds.
declarations.title: findLastIndex

declarations.comments:
Insert an element into a list at the specified index, returning a new
list or `Nothing` if the index is out-of-bounds.

This function differs from the strict equivalent in that out-of-bounds arguments
result in the element being appended at the _end_ of the list.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: insertAt

declarations.comments:
Delete an element from a list at the specified index, returning a new
list or `Nothing` if the index is out-of-bounds.

This function differs from the strict equivalent in that out-of-bounds arguments
result in the original list being returned unchanged.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: deleteAt

declarations.comments:
Update the element at the specified index, returning a new
list or `Nothing` if the index is out-of-bounds.

This function differs from the strict equivalent in that out-of-bounds arguments
result in the original list being returned unchanged.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: updateAt

declarations.comments:
Update the element at the specified index by applying a function to
the current value, returning a new list or `Nothing` if the index is
out-of-bounds.

This function differs from the strict equivalent in that out-of-bounds arguments
result in the original list being returned unchanged.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: modifyAt

declarations.comments:
Update or delete the element at the specified index by applying a
function to the current value, returning a new list or `Nothing` if the
index is out-of-bounds.

This function differs from the strict equivalent in that out-of-bounds arguments
result in the original list being returned unchanged.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: alterAt

declarations.comments:
Reverse a list.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: reverse

declarations.comments:
Flatten a list of lists.

Running time: `O(n)`, where `n` is the total number of elements.
declarations.title: concat

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to each element in a list, and flatten the results
into a single, new list.

Running time: `O(n)`, where `n` is the total number of elements.
declarations.title: concatMap

declarations.comments:
Filter a list, keeping the elements which satisfy a predicate function.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: filter

declarations.comments:
Filter where the predicate returns a monadic `Boolean`.

For example:

```purescript
powerSet :: forall a. [a] -> [[a]]
powerSet = filterM (const [true, false])
```
declarations.title: filterM

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to each element in a list, keeping only the results which
contain a value.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: mapMaybe

declarations.comments:
Filter a list of optional values, keeping only the elements which contain
a value.
declarations.title: catMaybes

declarations.comments: A newtype used in cases where there is a list to be matched.
declarations.title: Pattern

declarations.comments:
If the list starts with the given prefix, return the portion of the
list left after removing it, as a Just value. Otherwise, return Nothing.
* `stripPrefix (Pattern (fromFoldable [1])) (fromFoldable [1,2]) == Just (fromFoldable [2])`
* `stripPrefix (Pattern (fromFoldable [])) (fromFoldable [1]) == Just (fromFoldable [1])`
* `stripPrefix (Pattern (fromFoldable [2])) (fromFoldable [1]) == Nothing`

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the number of elements to strip.
declarations.title: stripPrefix

declarations.comments: Extract a sublist by a start and end index.
declarations.title: slice

declarations.comments:
Take the specified number of elements from the front of a list.

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the number of elements to take.
declarations.title: take

declarations.comments:
Take those elements from the front of a list which match a predicate.

Running time (worst case): `O(n)`
declarations.title: takeWhile

declarations.comments:
Drop the specified number of elements from the front of a list.

Running time: `O(n)` where `n` is the number of elements to drop.
declarations.title: drop

declarations.comments:
Drop those elements from the front of a list which match a predicate.

Running time (worst case): `O(n)`
declarations.title: dropWhile

declarations.comments:
Split a list into two parts:

1. the longest initial segment for which all elements satisfy the specified predicate
2. the remaining elements

For example,

```purescript
span (\n -> n % 2 == 1) (1 : 3 : 2 : 4 : 5 : Nil) == Tuple (1 : 3 : Nil) (2 : 4 : 5 : Nil)
```

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: span

declarations.comments:
Group equal, consecutive elements of a list into lists.

For example,

```purescript
group (1 : 1 : 2 : 2 : 1 : Nil) == (1 : 1 : Nil) : (2 : 2 : Nil) : (1 : Nil) : Nil
```

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: group

declarations.comments:
Group equal, consecutive elements of a list into lists, using the specified
equivalence relation to determine equality.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: groupBy

declarations.comments:
Returns a tuple of lists of elements which do
and do not satisfy a predicate, respectively.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: partition

declarations.comments:
Remove duplicate elements from a list.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: nub

declarations.comments:
Remove duplicate elements from a list, using the specified
function to determine equality of elements.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: nubBy

declarations.comments:
Calculate the union of two lists.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: union

declarations.comments:
Calculate the union of two lists, using the specified
function to determine equality of elements.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: unionBy

declarations.comments:
Delete the first occurrence of an element from a list.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: delete

declarations.comments:
Delete the first occurrence of an element from a list, using the specified
function to determine equality of elements.

Running time: `O(n)`
declarations.title: deleteBy

declarations.comments:
Delete the first occurrence of each element in the second list from the first list.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: difference

declarations.comments:
Calculate the intersection of two lists.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: intersect

declarations.comments:
Calculate the intersection of two lists, using the specified
function to determine equality of elements.

Running time: `O(n^2)`
declarations.title: intersectBy

declarations.comments:
Apply a function to pairs of elements at the same positions in two lists,
collecting the results in a new list.

If one list is longer, elements will be discarded from the longer list.

For example

```purescript
zipWith (*) (1 : 2 : 3 : Nil) (4 : 5 : 6 : 7 Nil) == 4 : 10 : 18 : Nil
```

Running time: `O(min(m, n))`
declarations.title: zipWith

declarations.comments:
A generalization of `zipWith` which accumulates results in some `Applicative`
functor.
declarations.title: zipWithA

declarations.comments:
Collect pairs of elements at the same positions in two lists.

Running time: `O(min(m, n))`
declarations.title: zip

declarations.comments:
Transforms a list of pairs into a list of first components and a list of
second components.
declarations.title: unzip

declarations.comments:
The 'transpose' function transposes the rows and columns of its argument.
For example,

    transpose ((1:2:3:nil) : (4:5:6:nil) : nil) ==
      ((1:4:nil) : (2:5:nil) : (3:6:nil) : nil)

If some of the rows are shorter than the following rows, their elements are skipped:

    transpose ((10:11:nil) : (20:nil) : nil : (30:31:32:nil) : nil) ==
      ((10:20:30:nil) : (11:31:nil) : (32:nil) : nil)
declarations.title: transpose

declarations.comments: Perform a fold using a monadic step function.
declarations.title: foldM

declarations.comments: Perform a right fold lazily
declarations.title: foldrLazy

declarations.comments: Perform a right scan lazily
declarations.title: scanrLazy
